The **urinary system** , also known as the **renal system** , consists of the
[kidneys](/wiki/Kidneys "Kidneys"), [ureters](/wiki/Ureters "Ureters"),
[bladder](/wiki/Urinary_bladder "Urinary bladder"), and the
[urethra](/wiki/Urethra "Urethra"). Each kidney consists of functional units
called [nephrons](/wiki/Nephrons "Nephrons"). The purpose of the renal system
is to eliminate waste from the body, regulate blood volume and blood pressure,
control levels of electrolytes and metabolites, and regulate blood pH. The
kidneys have an extensive blood supply via the renal arteries which leave the
kidneys via the renal vein. Following filtration of blood and further
processing, wastes (in the form of [urine](/wiki/Urine "Urine")) exit the
kidney via the ureters, tubes made of smooth muscle fibres that propel urine
towards the urinary bladder, where it is stored and subsequently expelled from
the body by [urination](/wiki/Urination "Urination") ([voiding](/wiki/Voiding
"Voiding")). The female and male urinary system are very similar, differing
only in the length of the urethra.[1]

Urine is formed in the kidneys through a filtration of [blood](/wiki/Blood
"Blood"). The urine is then passed through the ureters to the bladder, where
it is stored. During urination, the urine is passed from the bladder through
the urethra to the outside of the body.

800–2,000 [milliliters](/wiki/Milliliters "Milliliters") (mL) of urine are
normally produced every day in a healthy human. This amount varies according
to fluid intake and kidney function.

## Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Urinary_system&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Structure")]

The urinary system refers to the structures that produce and transport urine
to the point of excretion. In the human urinary system there are two kidneys
that are located between the dorsal body wall and parietal peritoneum on both
the left and right sides.

The formation of urine begins within the functional unit of the kidney, the
nephrons. Urine then flows through the nephrons, through a system of
converging tubules called collecting ducts. These collecting ducts then join
together to form the minor calyces, followed by the major calyces that
ultimately join the renal pelvis. From here, urine continues its flow from the
renal pelvis into the ureter, transporting urine into the urinary bladder. The
anatomy of the human urinary system differs between males and females at the
level of the urinary bladder. In males, the urethra begins at the internal
urethral orifice in the trigone of the bladder, continues through the external
urethral orifice, and then becomes the prostatic, membranous, bulbar, and
penile urethra. Urine exits through the external urethral meatus. The female
urethra is much shorter, beginning at the bladder neck and terminating in the
vaginal vestibule.

### Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Urinary_system&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Development")]

Main article: [Development of the urinary
system](/wiki/Development_of_the_urinary_system "Development of the urinary
system")

###
Microanatomy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Urinary_system&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Microanatomy")]

See also: [Urothelium](/wiki/Urothelium "Urothelium")

Under microscopy, the urinary system is covered in a unique lining called
[urothelium](/wiki/Urothelium "Urothelium"), a type of [transitional
epithelium](/wiki/Transitional_epithelium "Transitional epithelium"). Unlike
the [epithelial](/wiki/Epithelium "Epithelium") lining of most organs,
transitional epithelium can flatten and distend. Urothelium covers most of the
urinary system, including the renal pelvis, ureters, and bladder.

## Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Urinary_system&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Function")]

The main functions of the urinary system and it's components are to

  * Regulate [blood volume](/wiki/Blood_volume "Blood volume") and composition (e.g. [sodium](/wiki/Sodium "Sodium"), [potassium](/wiki/Potassium "Potassium") and [calcium](/wiki/Calcium "Calcium"))
  * Regulate [blood pressure](/wiki/Blood_pressure "Blood pressure").
  * Regulate [pH](/wiki/PH "PH") [homeostasis](/wiki/Homeostasis "Homeostasis") of the blood.
  * Contributes to the production of red blood cells by the [kidney](/wiki/Kidney "Kidney").
  * Helps synthesize [calcitrol](/wiki/Calcitrol "Calcitrol") the (active form of [Vitamin D](/wiki/Vitamin_D "Vitamin D")).
  * Stores waste product (mainly [urea](/wiki/Urea "Urea") and [uric acid](/wiki/Uric_acid "Uric acid")) before it and other products are removed from the body.

### Urine
formation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Urinary_system&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Urine formation")]

Average urine production in adult humans is about 1–2 [litres](/wiki/Litres
"Litres") (L) per day, depending on state of hydration, activity level,
environmental factors, weight, and the individual's health. Producing too much
or too little urine requires medical attention. [Polyuria](/wiki/Polyuria
"Polyuria") is a condition of excessive urine production (> 2.5 L/day).
[Oliguria](/wiki/Oliguria "Oliguria") when < 400 mL (millilitres) are
produced, and [anuria](/wiki/Anuria "Anuria") one of < 100 mL per day.

The first step in urine formation is the filtration of blood in the kidneys.
In a healthy human the kidney receives between 12 and 30% of [cardiac
output](/wiki/Cardiac_output "Cardiac output"), but it averages about 20% or
about 1.25 L/min.

The basic structural and functional unit of the kidney is the
[nephron](/wiki/Nephron "Nephron"). Its chief function is to regulate the
[concentration](/wiki/Concentration "Concentration") of [water](/wiki/Water
"Water") and soluble substances like [sodium](/wiki/Sodium_salt "Sodium salt")
by filtering the [blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood"), reabsorbing what is needed and
excreting the rest as [urine](/wiki/Urine "Urine").

In the first part of the nephron, [Bowman's capsule](/wiki/Bowman%27s_capsule
"Bowman's capsule") filters blood from the [circulatory
system](/wiki/Circulatory_system "Circulatory system") into the tubules.
Hydrostatic and osmotic pressure gradients facilitate filtration across a
semipermeable membrane. The filtrate includes water, small molecules, and ions
that easily pass through the filtration membrane. However larger molecules
such as [proteins](/wiki/Proteins "Proteins") and [blood
cells](/wiki/Blood_cell "Blood cell") are prevented from passing through the
filtration membrane. The amount of filtrate produced every minute is called
the [glomerular filtration rate](/wiki/Glomerular_filtration_rate "Glomerular
filtration rate") or GFR and amounts to 180 litres per day. About 99% of this
filtrate is reabsorbed as it passes through the nephron and the remaining 1%
becomes urine.

The urinary system is regulated by the [endocrine
system](/wiki/Endocrine_system "Endocrine system") by [hormones](/wiki/Hormone
"Hormone") such as [antidiuretic hormone](/wiki/Antidiuretic_hormone
"Antidiuretic hormone"), [aldosterone](/wiki/Aldosterone "Aldosterone"), and
[parathyroid hormone](/wiki/Parathyroid_hormone "Parathyroid hormone").[2]

#### Regulation of concentration and
volume[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Urinary_system&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Regulation of concentration and volume")]

The urinary system is under influence of the [circulatory
system](/wiki/Circulatory_system "Circulatory system"), [nervous
system](/wiki/Nervous_system "Nervous system"), and [endocrine
system](/wiki/Endocrine_system "Endocrine system").

[Aldosterone](/wiki/Aldosterone "Aldosterone") plays a central role in
regulating blood pressure through its effects on the kidney. It acts on the
distal tubules and collecting ducts of the nephron and increases reabsorption
of sodium from the glomerular filtrate. Reabsorption of sodium results in
retention of water, which increases blood pressure and blood volume.
Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), is a [neurohypophysial
hormone](/wiki/Neurohypophysial_hormone "Neurohypophysial hormone") found in
most [mammals](/wiki/Mammals "Mammals"). Its two primary functions are to
retain water in the body and [vasoconstriction](/wiki/Vasoconstriction
"Vasoconstriction"). Vasopressin regulates the body's [retention of
water](/wiki/Water_retention_\(medicine\) "Water retention \(medicine\)") by
increasing water reabsorption in the collecting ducts of the kidney
nephron.[3] Vasopressin increases water permeability of the kidney's
collecting duct and distal convoluted tubule by inducing translocation of
aquaporin-CD water channels in the kidney nephron collecting duct plasma
membrane.[4]

### Urination[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Urinary_system&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Urination")]

Main article: [Urination](/wiki/Urination "Urination")

Urination is the ejection of [urine](/wiki/Urine "Urine") from the [urinary
bladder](/wiki/Urinary_bladder "Urinary bladder") through the
[urethra](/wiki/Urethra "Urethra") to the outside of the body. In healthy
humans (and [many other animals](/wiki/Urination#Animals "Urination")), the
process of urination is under voluntary control. In infants, some elderly
individuals, and those with neurological injury, urination may occur as an
involuntary [reflex](/wiki/Reflex "Reflex"). Physiologically, micturition
involves coordination between the [central](/wiki/Central_nervous_system
"Central nervous system"), [autonomic](/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system
"Autonomic nervous system"), and [somatic nervous
systems](/wiki/Somatic_nervous_system "Somatic nervous system"). Brain centers
that regulate urination include the [pontine micturition
center](/wiki/Pontine_micturition_center "Pontine micturition center"),
[periaqueductal gray](/wiki/Periaqueductal_gray "Periaqueductal gray"), and
the [cerebral cortex](/wiki/Cerebral_cortex "Cerebral cortex"). In [placental
mammals](/wiki/Placentalia "Placentalia") the male ejects urine through the
[penis](/wiki/Penis "Penis"), and the female through the [vulva](/wiki/Vulva
"Vulva").

## Clinical
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Urinary_system&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Clinical significance")]

Main article: [Urologic disease](/wiki/Urologic_disease "Urologic disease")

[Urologic disease](/wiki/Urologic_disease "Urologic disease") can involve
congenital or acquired dysfunction of the urinary system.

Diseases of the kidney tissue are normally treated by
[nephrologists](/wiki/Nephrologist "Nephrologist"), while disease of the
urinary tract are treated by [urologists](/wiki/Urologist "Urologist").
[Gynecologists](/wiki/Gynecology "Gynecology") may also treat female urinary
incontinence.

Diseases of other bodily systems also have a direct effect on urogenital
function. For instance it has been shown that [protein](/wiki/Protein
"Protein") released by the kidneys in [diabetes
mellitus](/wiki/Diabetes_mellitus "Diabetes mellitus") sensitises the kidney
to the damaging effects of [hypertension](/wiki/Hypertension
"Hypertension").[5]

[Diabetes](/wiki/Diabetes "Diabetes") also can have a direct effect in
[urination](/wiki/Urination "Urination") due to [peripheral
neuropathies](/wiki/Peripheral_neuropathy "Peripheral neuropathy") which occur
in some individuals with poorly controlled diabetes.[6]

[Urinary incontinence](/wiki/Urinary_incontinence "Urinary incontinence") can
result from a weakening of the [pelvic floor](/wiki/Pelvic_floor "Pelvic
floor") muscles caused by factors such as [pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy
"Pregnancy"), [childbirth](/wiki/Childbirth "Childbirth"),
[aging](/wiki/Ageing "Ageing") and being [overweight](/wiki/Overweight
"Overweight"). Pelvic floor exercises known as [Kegel
exercises](/wiki/Kegel_exercise "Kegel exercise") can help in this condition
by strengthening the pelvic floor. There can also be underlying medical
reasons for urinary incontinence which are often treatable. In children the
condition is called [enuresis](/wiki/Enuresis "Enuresis").

Some cancers also target the urinary system, including [bladder
cancer](/wiki/Bladder_cancer "Bladder cancer"), [kidney
cancer](/wiki/Kidney_cancer "Kidney cancer"), [uteral
cancer](/w/index.php?title=Uteral_cancer&action=edit&redlink=1 "Uteral cancer
\(page does not exist\)"), and [urethral cancer](/wiki/Urethral_cancer
"Urethral cancer"). Due to the role and location of these organs, treatment is
often complicated.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
